cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who is the owner of the crowne plaza
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
1. The Crowne Plaza is a brand of hotels that is part of a larger hotel group.
2. To determine the owner, I need to identify the parent company that manages the Crowne Plaza brand.
3. Crowne Plaza is owned by InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which is a multinational hotel company.
4. IHG operates several hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental Hotels.

Answer:
The owner of the Crowne Plaza is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG).

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who is the owner of the crowne plaza
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold the hotel building to a new owner, EOS DCH Owner LLC, for $106.5 million. The hotel disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, and became an independent property.\n', "In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of the building for €138.6 million, committing to purchase the remaining 50% belonging to the hotel shortly thereafter. The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.\n", 'It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.\n', 'As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.\n', 'In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.\n', 'In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".\n', 'Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta\'s Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.\n', "The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.\n", 'In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.\n', 'Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question of who owns the Crowne Plaza, we can extract and analyze relevant information from the provided passages. Here are the key points and their implications:

1. **Ownership Changes**:
   - The passages indicate that ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels has changed multiple times. For instance, one passage mentions that in September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold a hotel building to EOS DCH Owner LLC, which then disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand. This suggests that ownership can significantly impact branding and management decisions.
   - Another passage discusses a sale in mid-2010 to Hargate Properties, which retained the Crowne Plaza affiliation but later went into receivership. This indicates that financial stability is crucial for maintaining brand affiliation.

2. **Investment and Development**:
   - The passage about Optima Ventures and Sage Hospitality Resources acquiring the Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel highlights the role of investment firms and hotel developers in ownership. This suggests that ownership can often involve partnerships and joint ventures, complicating the identification of a single owner.
   - The mention of Gabriel Ruiz, a Mexico-based developer, as a purchaser who planned to enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts indicates that ownership may not always equate to operational control, as management agreements can allow brands to maintain their presence even when ownership changes.

3. **Brand Affiliation**:
   - The Crowne Plaza brand is part of InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which is a significant player in the hospitality industry. This affiliation means that while individual hotels may have different owners, they operate under the Crowne Plaza brand umbrella, which is managed by IHG. This is crucial for understanding the brand's identity and operational standards.

4. **Geographical Variability**:
   - The passages mention various Crowne Plaza locations, including Hong Kong and Christchurch, New Zealand. This geographical diversity indicates that ownership structures may vary by region, influenced by local market conditions and investment opportunities.

5. **Financial Transactions**:
   - The financial details provided in the passages (e.g., sale prices, investment amounts) illustrate the economic aspects of hotel ownership. Understanding these financial transactions can help contextualize the value and market dynamics of Crowne Plaza properties.

### Role of Extracted Content:
The extracted content provides a multifaceted view of Crowne Plaza ownership, highlighting the complexities involved in hotel management and branding. It emphasizes that ownership can change frequently and may involve various stakeholders, including investment firms, developers, and management companies. This understanding is essential for answering the question about ownership, as it illustrates that the Crowne Plaza brand may not have a single owner but rather a network of owners and operators across different locations.

### Conclusion:
In summary, the ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels is not straightforward and involves various entities and financial arrangements. The model should recognize that while specific hotels may have different owners, they are often part of a larger brand managed by a parent company, in this case, InterContinental Hotels Group. This complexity is crucial for accurately addressing questions about ownership in the hospitality industry.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Understanding Brand Ownership**:
   - The Crowne Plaza is a hotel brand that operates under the umbrella of a larger hotel group. This means that while individual hotels may have different owners, they are all part of a collective brand managed by a parent company.

2. **Identifying the Parent Company**:
   - The parent company of the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG). IHG is a multinational hotel company that manages several well-known hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental Hotels.

3. **Ownership Dynamics**:
   - Ownership of specific Crowne Plaza hotels can change frequently. For example, the passages indicate that hotels have been sold to various entities, such as EOS DCH Owner LLC and Hargate Properties, which retained the Crowne Plaza affiliation but faced financial difficulties. This highlights that while IHG manages the brand, individual hotels may have different owners who can affect the brand's operation and reputation.

4. **Management Agreements**:
   - Even when ownership changes, hotels may continue to operate under the Crowne Plaza brand through management agreements with IHG. This means that the operational control of the hotel can remain with IHG, even if the ownership of the property itself changes hands. This is crucial for understanding how the brand maintains consistency across different locations.

5. **Geographical Variability and Market Conditions**:
   - The Crowne Plaza brand has a global presence, with hotels in various countries, including Hong Kong and New Zealand. This geographical diversity can lead to different ownership structures and market dynamics, influenced by local economic conditions and investment opportunities.

6. **Financial Transactions and Stability**:
   - The financial aspects of hotel ownership, such as sale prices and investment amounts, are important for understanding the viability and stability of individual Crowne Plaza hotels. Financial health is essential for maintaining brand affiliation and operational standards.

### Conclusion:
The ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels is complex, involving various stakeholders and financial arrangements. While the brand is managed by InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), individual hotels may have different owners, and operational control can vary based on management agreements. This multifaceted understanding is crucial for accurately addressing questions about ownership in the hospitality industry.

### Answer:
The owner of the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which manages the brand. However, individual Crowne Plaza hotels may have different owners, as ownership can change frequently and may involve various stakeholders and management agreements.

   - In **March 2012**, the hotel was sold to an unnamed investor, later identified as **Gabriel Ruiz**, who planned renovations and a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts.
   - **Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay** is owned by the **SEA Group**, which has a diverse portfolio in property investments and developments.

2. **Causal Relationships**:

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
who is the owner of the crowne plaza
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold the hotel building to a new owner, EOS DCH Owner LLC, for $106.5 million. The hotel disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, and became an independent property.\n', "In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of the building for €138.6 million, committing to purchase the remaining 50% belonging to the hotel shortly thereafter. The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.\n", 'It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.\n', 'As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.\n', 'In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.\n', 'In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".\n', 'Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta\'s Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.\n', "The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.\n", 'In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.\n', 'Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.\n']

1. **Understanding the Brand Structure**: The Crowne Plaza is a brand of hotels that operates under the umbrella of a larger hotel group. The primary parent company that manages the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG).

2. **Ownership Dynamics**: Ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels can change frequently. While IHG manages the brand, individual hotels may be owned by different entities. For instance, one passage mentions that a Crowne Plaza hotel was sold to an unnamed investor who intended to enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, indicating that IHG does not necessarily own all properties branded as Crowne Plaza.

3. **Specific Ownership Examples**: The Crowne Plaza in Hong Kong Causeway Bay is specifically noted as being owned by the SEA Group. This illustrates that different Crowne Plaza locations can have different owners, which is essential for understanding the brand's structure and the nature of its operations.

**Answer**: The owner of the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG). question_info.question: who is the owner of the crowne plaza
passages:
In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold the hotel building to a new owner, EOS DCH Owner LLC, for $106.5 million. The hotel disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, and became an independent property.
In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of the building for €138.6 million, committing to purchase the remaining 50% belonging to the hotel shortly thereafter. The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.
It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.
As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.
In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.
In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".
Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta's Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.
The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.
In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.
Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.
